entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 2 at 11:00PM CST by NWS Fort Worth TX
entry.summary:
At 1059 PM CST, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm over Whitesboro, moving east at 40 mph.
HAZARD...Winds in excess of 40 mph.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects.
This strong thunderstorm will be near... Whitesboro and Lake Texoma around 1105 PM CST. Pottsboro around 1115 PM CST. Denison around 1125 PM CST.
Other locations impacted by this storm include Cannon, Preston, Tioga, Ida, Sadler, Elmont, Locust, Pilot Grove, Lake Ray Roberts, and Luella.
This includes Interstate 35 between mile markers 495 and 503.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cooke; Grayson

cap:parameter.value: A strong thunderstorm will impact portions of eastern Cooke and Grayson Counties through 1130 PM CST

entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued February 2 at 10:54PM CST until February 2 at 11:30PM CST by NWS Fort Worth TX
entry.summary:
SVRFWD
The National Weather Service in Fort Worth has issued a
* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for... Northwestern Ellis County in north central Texas... Southern Dallas County in north central Texas...
* Until 1130 PM CST.
* At 1054 PM CST, a severe thunderstorm was located near Midlothian, moving northeast at 45 mph.
HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Expect damage to roofs, siding, and trees.
* This severe thunderstorm will be near... Dallas, Desoto, Cedar Hill, Duncanville, Glenn Heights, Ovilla, and Oak Leaf around 1100 PM CST. Lancaster and Red Oak around 1105 PM CST. Hutchins and Wilmer around 1110 PM CST. Balch Springs and Seagoville around 1120 PM CST.
Other locations impacted by this severe thunderstorm include Trumbull, Pecan Hill, Joe Pool Lake, Sand Branch, Rockett, India, Bristol, White Rock Lake, Mountain Creek Lake, and Griffith.
This includes the following highways... Interstate 35E between mile markers 400 and 428. Interstate 20 between mile markers 455 and 479. Interstate 30 between mile markers 43 and 53. Interstate 45 between mile markers 260 and 284.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Dallas, TX; Ellis, TX

entry.title: Wind Advisory issued February 2 at 9:42PM MST until February 3 at 5:00AM MST by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Wind Advisory, west winds 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 50 mph. For the High Wind Warning, west winds 35 to 45 mph with gusts up to 65 mph expected.
* WHERE...South Central Mountains and Southwest Chaves County.
* WHEN...For the Wind Advisory, until 5 AM MST Saturday. For the High Wind Warning, from 5 AM Saturday to 5 AM MST Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Damaging winds could blow down trees and power lines. Power outages are possible. Travel will be difficult, especially for high profile vehicles.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The strongest winds will occur around Sierra Blanca, the Capitan Mountains, and State Highway 24. Areas of blowing dust may lower visibility.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued February 2 at 10:34PM CST until February 3 at 2:00AM CST by NWS Austin/San Antonio TX
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of south central Texas, including the following counties, Bastrop, Caldwell, DeWitt, Fayette, Gonzales, Guadalupe, Karnes, Lavaca and Wilson.
* WHEN...Until 200 AM CST.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1033 PM CST, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Up to 1 inch of rain has fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts up to 2 inches are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. These areas has upwards of 10 inches of rain recently and runoff will be rapid. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Seguin, Lockhart, Cuero, Bastrop, Gonzales, Floresville, Yoakum, Luling, La Grange, Smithville, Schulenburg, Hallettsville, Poth, Shiner, Stockdale, Flatonia, Moulton, Kosciusko, Nixon and La Vernia. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Bastrop, TX; Caldwell, TX; DeWitt, TX; Fayette, TX; Gonzales, TX; Guadalupe, TX; Karnes, TX; Lavaca, TX; Wilson, TX

entry.summary:

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued February 2 at 8:18PM PST until February 6 at 6:00PM PST by NWS San Diego CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Light snow will occur Sunday afternoon through Monday afternoon with windy conditions and gusts 50-60 mph. Heavy snow expected at times Monday evening through Tuesday evening. Between Sunday evening and Tuesday evening, snow totals of 6 inches or more could occur as low as 6,000 feet with up to a foot of snow between 7,000 and 8,000 feet. Locations above 8,000 feet could get as much as 2 feet of snow.
* WHERE...Areas above 6,000 feet in San Bernardino County Mountains and Riverside County Mountains.
* WHEN...From Saturday evening through Tuesday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening commute. Strong winds could cause tree damage.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Light snow and rain showers will mix in at times through Monday, changing to all snow by Monday evening.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Bernardino County Mountains; Riverside County Mountains

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued February 2 at 8:06PM PST until February 4 at 9:00AM PST by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves with dangerous rip currents. Surf 10 to 14 feet with local sets up to 16 feet through Saturday for northwest facing beaches. Swell will switch southerly Saturday night into Sunday, and south facing beaches will see surf 14 to 18 feet with local to 20 feet, peaking on Sunday. For the Coastal Flood Advisory, minor coastal flooding is expected near time of high tide early Sunday morning for south facing locations, such as Port San Luis, Avila Beach, Oceano, and Cayucos.
* WHERE...San Luis Obispo County Beaches and Santa Barbara County Central Coast Beaches.
* WHEN...For the High Surf Advisory, until 9 PM PST Monday. For the Coastal Flood Advisory, from 1 AM to 9 AM PST Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of sea water is likely, around the time of high tide, over vulnerable low-lying coastal areas such as parking lots, beaches, and walkways. Significant damage to roads or structures is NOT expected. There is an increased risk for ocean drowning. Rip currents can pull swimmers and surfers out to sea. Large breaking waves can cause injury, wash people off beaches and rocks, and capsize small boats near shore.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Due to the combination of strong southerly winds gusting to 40 knots and lower atmospheric pressure, water levels may approach 6.5 to 7 feet near the time of high tide which is around 430 AM Sunday. These higher water levels combined with waves over 10 feet will make the Central Coast vulnerable to coastal flooding.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Luis Obispo County Beaches; Santa Barbara County Central Coast Beaches

cap:parameter.value: HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 PM PST MONDAY... ...COASTAL FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 1 AM TO 9 AM PST SUNDAY

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Moderate coastal flooding is expected for SOUTH facing harbors on early Monday morning. This includes areas like Santa Barbara Harbor.

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued February 2 at 8:59PM MST until February 4 at 5:00PM MST by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow developing tonight with a period moderate to heavy snow expected Saturday afternoon and evening. Total snow accumulations between 5 and 10 inches.
* WHERE...Big Belt, Bridger and Castle Mountains, Elkhorn and Boulder Mountains, Little Belt and Highwood Mountains, Upper Blackfoot and MacDonald Pass, and Gallatin and Madison County Mountains and Centennial Mountains.

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued February 2 at 6:58PM PST until February 4 at 10:00PM PST by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow. Snow accumulations in the lowest valley locations of 3 to 6 inches, including the downtown portions of Reno, Sparks, and Carson City, with 14 to 20 inches in the Virginia City Highlands. Snow accumulations of 6 to 12 inches above 5000 feet across western foothill locations, and 1 to 2 feet above 6000 feet. Winds gusting as high as 60 mph along higher peaks, with valleys seeing gusts 30 to 40 mph. Winds gusting as high 65 mph along wind prone areas of US-395 and US-95.
* WHERE...Greater Reno-Carson City-Minden Area and Mineral and Southern Lyon Counties.
* WHEN...From 10 PM Saturday to 10 PM PST Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could become difficult to impossible with snowfall rates of 2 to 3 inches per hour possible at times. Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will likely become slick and hazardous. Whiteout conditions are expected and will make travel treacherous and potentially life-threatening. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday morning commute. Very strong winds could cause extensive damage to trees and power lines.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow will develop early Sunday morning along western leeside foothills of the Sierra. Snow will continue to intensify through the day Sunday, with snow levels between 5000 to 6000 feet.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Mineral and Southern Lyon Counties; Greater Reno-Carson City-Minden Area

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 10 PM SATURDAY TO 10 PM PST SUNDAY

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued February 2 at 6:58PM PST until February 5 at 10:00AM PST by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow. Snow accumulations of 2 to 8 inches below 4500 feet, 1 to 2 feet between 4500 and 6500 feet, and up to 3 feet above 6500 feet. Winds gusting as high as 55 mph along Sierra ridges, with gusts in valleys as high as 45 mph.
* WHERE...Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties.
* WHEN...From 10 PM Saturday to 10 AM PST Monday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible with snowfall rates up to 2 inches per hour possible. Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will likely become slick and hazardous. Whiteout conditions are expected and will make travel treacherous and potentially life-threatening. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday morning commute. Strong winds could cause extensive damage to trees and power lines.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow will begin early Sunday morning along western leeside foothills of the Sierra. Snow will continue to intensify through the day Sunday, with snow levels between 5000 to 5500 feet.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 10 PM SATURDAY TO 10 AM PST MONDAY

Pearl River Near Bogalusa affecting Washington and Pearl River Counties.
For the Lower Pearl River...including Bogalusa, Pearl River...Minor flooding is forecast.

entry.title: Avalanche Watch issued February 2 at 3:41PM PST by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
AVAREV
The following message is transmitted at the request of the U.S. Forest Service Sierra Avalanche Center.
BACKCOUNTRY AVALANCHE WATCH
IMMEDIATE BROADCAST REQUESTED
07:00 PST Sun Feb 04 2024
The Sierra Avalanche Center in Truckee has issued a BACKCOUNTRY AVALANCHE WATCH for the following areas: NWS Reno NV - NVZ002 Greater Lake Tahoe...CAZ072 Greater Lake Tahoe, CA
* WHAT...Periods of HIGH avalanche danger are expected to occur in the backcountry from Sunday into early Tuesday morning.
* WHERE...Central Sierra Nevada Mountains between Yuba Pass (Hwy 49) on the north and Ebbetts Pass (Hwy 4) on the south, including the greater Lake Tahoe area. This does not include ski areas and highways where avalanche mitigation programs exist.
* WHEN...In effect from Sun 07:00 PST to Tue 07:00 PST.
* IMPACTS...Winter storms with new snow and strong winds may result in widespread avalanche activity in the mountains. Large avalanches could occur in a variety of backcountry areas.
* PRECAUTIONARY / PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...Very dangerous avalanche conditions may occur. Traveling in, near, or below backcountry avalanche terrain is not recommended during HIGH avalanche danger.
Consult https://www.sierraavalanchecenter.org/ or www.avalanche.org for more detailed information.
Similar avalanche danger may exist at locations outside the coverage area of this or any avalanche center.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Greater Lake Tahoe Area

entry.title: Wind Chill Advisory issued February 2 at 2:32PM AKST until February 3 at 9:00AM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...ACCUMULATING SNOW FOR THIS WEEKEND...
.A weak frontal wave will bring accumulating snow for most of the panhandle Saturday morning through Saturday evening. Juneau and Petersburg have the highest likelihood to achieve greater than 4 inches in a 12 hour period. Current dry and cold conditions will continue and yield ideal conditions for powdery, fast accumulating snow.
Another front associated with a weakening low pressure system moving into the northern gulf will bring more snow to the NE gulf coast throughout the day Sunday. The heaviest snowfall rates are expected along the outer coast from Yakutat down to Lisianski Strait as the front loses forward momentum in the face of continuing northerly outflow winds ahead of it.
* WHAT...Very cold wind chills expected. Wind chills as low as 40 below zero.
* WHERE...Klondike Highway.
* WHEN...From 5 PM this afternoon to 9 AM AKST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...The dangerously cold wind chills could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 10 minutes.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Municipality of Skagway

entry.title: Flood Watch issued February 2 at 2:08PM PST until February 5 at 10:00AM PST by NWS San Francisco CA
entry.summary:
Model solutions continues to vary as to where the greatest accumulation of precipitation will fall. Some models aim the Atmospheric River toward the Central Coast while others aim it a bit farther north towards the Santa Cruz Mountains. Currently thinking the greatest accumulation will be seen across the southern portion of the region with 2 to 3 inches over the interior portions of Monterey and San Benito Counties and 4 to 6 inches over the Santa Cruz Mountains, Big Sur coast and Santa Lucia Mountains. Locally up to 6 to 8 inches over favored peaks and higher terrain of the the Santa Cruz and Santa Lucia Mountains. Elsewhere rainfall totals will range from 2 to 4 inches across the North Bay with 5 inches possible over higher terrain. Over the greater Bay Area 1.5 to 3 inches are likely.
* WHAT...Flash flooding and debris flows caused by excessive rainfall are possible over the River Fire burn area.
* WHERE...A portion of the Northern Salinas Valley including but not limited to the 800 block of River Road, Pine Street, and Berry Drive.
* WHEN...From Saturday afternoon through Monday morning.
* IMPACTS...Heavy rainfall over the River Fire burn area is expected up to and during the period of the watch. Residents near the River Fire burn area should prepare for potential flooding impacts. Be sure to stay up to date with information from local authorities. Heavy rainfall could trigger flash flooding of low-lying areas, urbanized street flooding, hyper-concentrated mudflows, and debris flows in and near recent wildfire burn scars. Soils remain saturated and excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - National Weather Service Meteorologists are forecasting heavy rainfall over the River Fire burn area, which may lead to flash flooding and debris flows. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Santa Lucia Mountains and Los Padres National Forest; Northern Salinas Valley/Hollister Valley and Carmel Valley

entry.title: Flood Watch issued February 2 at 2:08PM PST until February 5 at 10:00AM PST by NWS San Francisco CA
entry.summary:
Model solutions continues to vary as to where the greatest accumulation of precipitation will fall. Some models aim the Atmospheric River toward the Central Coast while others aim it a bit farther north towards the Santa Cruz Mountains. Currently thinking the greatest accumulation will be seen across the southern portion of the region with 2 to 3 inches over the interior portions of Monterey and San Benito Counties and 4 to 6 inches over the Santa Cruz Mountains, Big Sur coast and Santa Lucia Mountains. Locally up to 6 to 8 inches over favored peaks and higher terrain of the the Santa Cruz and Santa Lucia Mountains. Elsewhere rainfall totals will range from 2 to 4 inches across the North Bay with 5 inches possible over higher terrain. Over the greater Bay Area 1.5 to 3 inches are likely.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Entire San Francisco Bay Area and Central Coast.
* WHEN...From Saturday afternoon through Monday morning.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas. Low-water crossings may be flooded. Storm drains and ditches may become clogged with debris. Extensive street flooding and flooding of creeks and rivers are possible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Periods of moderate to heavy rainfall will bring the potential for moderate to rapid rises along area rivers, streams, and creeks across the region. This could result in nuisance as well as minor flooding. Although many sites are forecast to remain below flood stage, several locations may reach and exceed flood stage across the region. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.summary:
* WHAT...Visibility one quarter mile or less in dense ice fog.
* WHERE...Eielson AFB and Salcha.
* WHEN...Until noon AKST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Hazardous driving conditions due to low visibility.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Areas of dense ice fog will continue through Saturday morning. Visibility can change rapidly making other vehicles difficult to see. Some areas will have visibility down to 100 feet. Drivers should give themselves extra time for travel and reduce speeds. Fog is expected to thin Saturday afternoon as temperatures begin to rise.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eielson AFB and Salcha; Fairbanks Metro Area

entry.title: Flood Watch issued February 2 at 1:57PM PST until February 4 at 6:00PM PST by NWS Eureka CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.
* WHERE...A portion of northwest California, including the following areas, Southeastern Mendocino Interior, Southern Lake and Southwestern Mendocino Interior.
* WHEN...From Sunday morning through Sunday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...There will be an increased risk of rock and land slides along roadways. Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Moderate to heavy rain is expected on Sunday. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southwestern Mendocino Interior; Southeastern Mendocino Interior; Southern Lake County

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued February 2 at 1:52PM PST until February 4 at 10:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Winter Storm Warning, heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 4 to 8 inches possible, with a foot or more of snow expected at elevations over 4000 feet. For the Winter Weather Advisory, snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 2 to 4 inches expected with up to 8 inches expected over higher terrain. Winds gusting as high as 40 mph.
* WHERE...For the Winter Storm Warning, areas of south central and eastern Siskiyou County. Affected roadways include Interstate 5 from north of Dunsmuir to Black Butte Summit, Highway 3 south of Callahan, parts of Highway 89 including Snowman Summit, and elevated terrain of Highway 97. Other affected communities include Bray, Tennant, and Pondosa. For the Winter Weather Advisory, areas of western Siskiyou County. Affected roadways include parts of Sawyers Bar Road near Mount Etna.
* WHEN...For the Winter Storm Warning, from 4 AM Sunday to 4 AM PST Monday. For the Winter Weather Advisory, from 4 AM to 10 PM PST Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning commute. Gusty winds may cause blowing snow and could further reduce visibility. Nighttime temperatures below freezing could refreeze liquid water or slushy snow, causing slippery road conditions.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Rising snow levels will significantly affect the timing and amount of snowfall for this event. Snow levels are forecast to start at 2000-2500 feet on Sunday morning and rise to 4000 feet by Monday morning. Most snowfall is expected from Sunday morning to Sunday evening, with impactful snow showers forecast to continue over Highway 89 at elevations above 4000 feet through early Monday morning.
* View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Siskiyou County; Central Siskiyou County; South Central Siskiyou County; North Central and Southeast Siskiyou County

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 2 at 9:28AM SST by NWS Pago Pago AS
entry.summary:
Active weather associated with the South Pacific Convergence Zone (SPCZ) will vamp up for the territory tonight. Expect strong winds and possible flash flooding conditions due to embedded low pressure systems to the west of the Samoa Island chain. These features are anticipated to move east and across territory through Sunday.
Although strong winds may briefly diminish Monday, there is a chance for possible tropical cyclone development near Wallis and Futuna for this time. Model consensus continues to move the potential tropical cyclone within our warning area (300 nautical miles of Tutuila) Tuesday through Wednesday. However, due to uncertainties in model data, we will keep you posted as we receive more information. Please visit our website at weather.gov/ppg for or call our office at 6999130 for the latest weather updates.
Definitions: South Pacific Convergence Zone - A band of intense rainfall and deep atmospheric convection extending from the equator to the subtropical South Pacific.
Low Pressure System - An area of converging winds and rotates in the same direction as the earth (General term, NOT ALWAYS a tropical cyclone as troughs are also low pressure systems)
Tropical Cyclone - A warm-core cyclone, originating over tropical or subtropical waters, with organized deep convection and a closed surface wind circulation about a well-defined center (23 mph winds or higher).
entry.cap:areaDesc: Tutuila and Aunuu; Manua; Swains Island

cap:parameter.value: Strong winds and flash flooding is expected tonight... ...Possible tropical cyclone development in the new week

entry.summary:
...CRITICAL FIRE WEATHER CONDITIONS EXPECTED SUNDAY MORNING THROUGH LATE SUNDAY EVENING...
.A cold front moves through south Texas Saturday morning reinforcing a surge of high pressure in its wake. A strong upper level jet is expected to mix towards the surface, allowing northwesterly winds to range between 25-35 mph, with gusts up to 50 mph. These winds coupled with low relative humidity values (15-30%) will pose a threat of fire weather conditions south and west of I-37.
The National Weather Service in Corpus Christi has issued a Fire Weather Watch for Critical Fire Weather Conditions, which is in effect from Sunday morning through Sunday evening.
* AFFECTED AREA...La Salle, McMullen, Live Oak, Webb, Duval, Jim Wells, Inland Kleberg and Inland Nueces.
* TIMING...9 AM to 9 PM Sunday.
* WINDS...Northwest 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 50 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 15 percent.
* TEMPERATURES...Up to 77.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended

* WHERE...San Luis Obispo, Santa Barbara, and Ventura Counties.
* WHEN...From late Saturday night through Tuesday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Creeks, streams, and smaller rivers, including the Ventura River, may rise out of their banks. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas. Low-water crossings may be flooded. Storm drains and ditches may become clogged with debris. Extensive street flooding and flooding of creeks and rivers are possible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - A very strong storm will move into southwest California later Saturday through Tuesday, with the heaviest period Sunday into Monday. Several inches of rain are expected during that period. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Avalanche Watch issued February 2 at 8:08AM MST by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
AVAABQ
The following message is transmitted at the request of the Taos Avalanche Center.
The Taos Avalanche Center in Taos has issued a Backcountry Avalanche Watch.
* WHAT...The avalanche danger is currently Moderate. A significant winter storm will intensify throughout the Northern NM mountains today, pushing the avalanche danger to High at all elevations by Saturday, February 3, 2024.
* WHERE...Wheeler Peak Wilderness Area and Columbine Hondo Wilderness above 8,000 feet.
* WHEN... In effect from Fri 07:00 MST to Sat 07:00 MST.
* IMPACTS...The winter storm will bring 12 to 20" of snow (1.5-2.0" SWE) and increasingly strong winds. Large dangerous natural and human-triggered avalanches are likely throughout the day Saturday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Sangre de Cristo Mountains

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued February 2 at 7:18AM MST by NWS Boise ID
entry.summary:
The following message is transmitted at the request of the Forest Service Sawtooth Avalanche Center.
...The Forest Service Sawtooth Avalanche Center in Ketchum Idaho has issued a BACKCOUNTRY AVALANCHE WARNING...
* WHAT...The avalanche danger is HIGH. Heavy snowfall and strong wind are overloading a very weak snowpack.
* WHERE...The southern Sawtooth, Soldier, Smoky, Boulder, Pioneer and mountains above the Wood River Valley and the mountains near Galena Summit, Trail Creek Summit, Smiley Creek and Ketchum, Hailey, Bellevue, Fairfield and Carey.
* WHEN...in effect until 4AM MST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Natural and human-triggered avalanches large enough to bury people are very likely to occur. Very large avalanches large enough to destroy houses may occur.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Camas, ID

entry.title: Avalanche Watch issued February 2 at 6:50AM MST by NWS Grand Junction CO
entry.summary:
AVAGJT
The following message is transmitted at the request of the Forest Service Utah Avalanche Center.
THE FOREST SERVICE UTAH AVALANCHE CENTER IN MOAB HAS ISSUED A BACKCOUNTRY AVALANCHE WATCH.
* TIMING: IN EFFECT FROM 6 AM MST THIS MORNING TO 6 AM MST SATURDAY.
* AFFECTED AREA: FOR THE LA SAL AND ABAJO MOUNTAINS OF SOUTHEASTERN UTAH
* AVALANCHE DANGER: DANGEROUS AVALANCHE CONDITIONS ARE DEVELOPING
* IMPACTS: A STRONG STORM SYSTEM ON FRIDAY IS EXPECTED TO INCREASE THE AVALANCHE DANGER WITH DANGEROUS CONDITIONS EXPECTED THROUGH THE WEEKEND. NATURAL AND HUMAN TRIGGERED AVALANCHES ARE LIKELY. TRAVEL IN AVALANCHE TERRAIN IS NOT RECOMMENDED. STAY OFF OF AND OUT FROM UNDER SLOPES STEEPER THAN 30 DEGREES.
BACKCOUNTRY TRAVELERS SHOULD CONSULT WWW.UTAHAVALANCHECENTER.ORG OR CALL 1-888-999-4019 FOR MORE DETAILED INFORMATION.
entry.cap:areaDesc: La Sal and Abajo Mountains

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued February 2 at 6:07AM MST by NWS Salt Lake City UT
entry.summary:
AVWSLC
* WHAT...The Avalanche danger is increasing. New snow landing on extremely weak existing snow is causing unstable conditions.
* WHERE...For the mountains of Southwestern Utah especially in the mountains near Cedar City as well as the Tushars.
* WHEN...In effect from 6AM MST Friday to 6AM MST Saturday. The warning will most likely be extended into Sunday.
* IMPACTS...A very unstable preexisting snowpack is getting overloaded by the weight of new snow. This will make human triggered avalanches very likely Friday and Saturday. People should avoid being on or below steep slopes in the mountains. Please help spread the word that dangerous avalanche conditions exist this weekend.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Mountains

entry.title: Flash Flood Watch issued February 1 at 7:47PM CST until February 3 at 6:00AM CST by NWS Memphis TN
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flash Flooding caused by a potential dam or levee failure continues to be possible at the Arkabutla Dam on the Coldwater River.
* WHERE...This is a potential dam breach watch declaration by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers Vicksburg District for Arkabutla Dam located in DeSoto and Tate Counties in Northwest Mississippi. The physical condition of the dam is unchanged, and a dam breach is not imminent. The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers Vicksburg District has increased the potential breach emergency status at Arkabutla Dam from ALERT to WATCH because of increasing reservoir levels due to the recent week long precipitation, and snow and ice melt.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...Dam failure may result in flash flooding of low-lying areas below the dam.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: DeSoto; Tunica; Tate; Coahoma; Quitman; Panola; Tallahatchie

entry.title: Avalanche Watch issued February 1 at 6:24PM MST by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
AVABOU
THE FOLLOWING MESSAGE IS TRANSMITTED AT THE REQUEST OF THE COLORADO AVALANCHE INFORMATION CENTER.
...AVALANCHE WATCH IN EFFECT FROM 5 PM THURSDAY UNTIL 5 PM SATURDAY
* WHAT... Dangerous avalanche conditions are taking shape. Expect the Avalanche Danger to rise to HIGH (Level 4 of 5) Friday night.
* WHERE... San Miguel Mountains, Sneffels Range, Rico Mountains, La Plata Mountains, Needles Range, San Juan and South San Juan Mountains.
* WHEN... Expect dangerous avalanche conditions to begin Friday night and last through Saturday at 5:00 PM.
* IMPACTS... Heavy snow falling on a weak base will create dangerous avalanche conditions by Saturday. Large and dangerous avalanches will be easy to trigger once the new snow accumulates. Avalanches will run naturally.
* PRECAUTION/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... Travel in backcountry avalanche terrain is not recommended on Saturday. Avoid travel on and under slopes with a slope angle steeper than about 30 degrees. You can find more detailed information at colorado.gov/avalanche
Pritchett
entry.cap:areaDesc: Uncompahgre Plateau/Dallas Divide; Northwestern San Juan Mountains; Southwest San Juan Mountains; Eastern San Juan Mountains Above 10000 Ft

entry.title: Avalanche Watch issued February 1 at 6:06PM MST by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
AVABOU
THE FOLLOWING MESSAGE IS TRANSMITTED AT THE REQUEST OF THE COLORADO AVALANCHE INFORMATION CENTER.
...AVALANCHE WATCH IN EFFECT FROM 5 PM THURSDAY UNTIL 5 PM SUNDAY
* WHAT... Dangerous avalanche conditions are taking shape. Expect the Avalanche Danger to rise to HIGH (Level 4 of 5) by mid-day Saturday.
* WHERE... Elkhead and Park Ranges, Medicine Bow Mountains, Never Summer Mountains, 10-Mile and Mosquito Ranges, and the Front Range including Rocky Mountain National Park.
* WHEN... Expect dangerous avalanche conditions to begin on Saturday by about Noon and last through Sunday at 5:00 PM.

* PRECAUTION/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... Travel in backcountry avalanche terrain is not recommended from Saturday afternoon through Sunday. Avoid travel on and under slopes with a slope angle steeper than about 30 degrees. You can find more detailed information at colorado.gov/avalanche
Pritchett

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued February 1 at 2:40AM MST by NWS Billings MT
entry.summary:
ESFBYZ
A storm system is expected to bring a mix of rain and snow this weekend. At elevations under 5000 feet precipitation may be mainly rain, and in other areas any snow that falls will melt quickly. With the ground frozen in most locations, this water will not be able to soak into the ground and will all runoff. Any rain that falls on snowpack in the foothills will likewise runoff rapidly. This water, flowing overland and accumulating in low lying areas, may result in localized flooding. Runoff flowing into ice covered creeks and streams will increase the potential for ice jam development, and may result in additional flooding near waterways.
Water may accumulate near home foundations increasing the chance of basement flooding. Plugged culverts, ditches, and storm drains may result in water on area roadways at times. Water flowing into creeks and streams will increase the potential for ice jam development with additional flooding hazards near waterways. Unpaved roads may suddenly thaw and become muddy and impassable. The severity of impacts will depend on how how much precipitation falls as rain or melting snow, and how fast the ground thaws.
While flooding is not imminent, now is the time to move equipment and livestock out of low lying areas, and away from waterways. Move any accumulations of snow away from structures and take steps to prevent water from making it into basements. Do not drive over flooded roadways as the roadbed may be washed out. Be especially careful driving at night when water covered roadways are less visible.
Stay tuned to the forecast for the latest temperature and precipitation trends, along with any warnings or advisories that may be issued. Please report any flooding to local law enforcement and have them relay the report to the National Weather Service.
